transcript:
Patient: If the thought "I'm not good enough to be in this program" were true, it would mean that I'm not capable of achieving my goals and that I'll never be able to make a difference in the lives of others through my work.

Therapist: I appreciate you sharing that, Noor. It's clear that this thought is deeply connected to your sense of self-worth and your aspirations. Let's explore this further by examining the evidence for and against this thought. Can you think of any experiences or feedback you've received that challenge the idea that you're not good enough to be in this program?

Patient: Well, I suppose there have been times when I've received positive feedback on my work. In fact, just last month, one of my professors praised my contribution to a class discussion and said that I had a unique perspective to offer.

Therapist: That's a great example of evidence against the thought that you're not good enough. Let's add that to the "Evidence Against" column in our thought record. Can you think of any other examples, perhaps from your personal life or your volunteer work, that challenge this negative thought?

Patient: Now that I think about it, there was a time when I was volunteering at the community center, and a young person came up to me and thanked me for sharing my story. They said it inspired them to seek help for their own struggles. That made me feel like I was making a difference, even if it was just for one person.

Therapist: That's another powerful piece of evidence against the thought that you're not good enough. It shows that your experiences and your willingness to share them have a positive impact on others. Let's add that to the "Evidence Against" column as well. Now, I'd like to challenge the thought "I'm not good enough to be in this program" by reframing it in a more balanced way. Based on the evidence we've gathered, what might be a more accurate and compassionate way to view this situation?

Patient: I guess a more balanced thought would be, "While I may have room for improvement, I also have unique strengths and experiences that contribute value to the program. One piece of critical feedback doesn't define my worth or my ability to make a difference."

Therapist: That's a wonderful reframe, Noor. It acknowledges the areas where you can grow while also recognizing your strengths and the value you bring. How does this new thought feel compared to the original negative thought?

Patient: It feels more hopeful and empowering. It reminds me that I'm not defined by one piece of feedback and that I have something valuable to offer.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that this reframe feels more empowering for you. As we continue to practice reframing negative thoughts, it's essential to remember that our thoughts are not always accurate reflections of reality. By examining the evidence and challenging our thoughts, we can develop a more balanced and compassionate perspective.
